Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This funding establishes a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Purdue University Calumet. Undergraduate students recruited from across the nation will participate in summer research projects focused on sustainable wireless communications. The research involves exploration of topics related to the almost pervasive use of devices such as smart phones and tablets that rely on wireless networks to communicate. The increasing use of these devices and applications is outstripping the capacity of the underlying network infrastructures. To accommodate the rising demand for ubiquitous high-speed data, researchers will need to design sustainable wireless networks that can function in the presence of the many challenges raised by the nature of wireless communications. This REU experience should help develop a group of computing professionals who can develop future communication systems that will be reliable, efficient, and sustainable.

The research projects span a variety of topics under the umbrella of sustainable wireless communications including spectrum-efficient wireless communication by means of reflected power, energy-efficient data dissemination in wireless sensor networks, adaptive backbone-based routing in delay tolerant wireless networks, adaptive network recovery from excessive network failure, and sustainable networks under intentional attacks. The program will target students from under-represented minorities and students from institutions that do not offer Ph.D degrees. The host institution, Purdue University Calumet, is a predominantly undergraduate institution with many students in the target group. Through hands-on projects and experiments, the program will provide students with an authentic environment to investigate effective solutions to real-world problems involving wireless communication technologies. The research activities coupled with other professional development opportunities all help achieve the project goal of inspiring students to pursue advance educational opportunities and professional careers in computer and information science.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of this proposal is to expose students to innovative research on the next generation of sustainable wireless communication, and to help them gain first-hand experience with state-of-the-art high-tech skills that are often inaccessible to them due to high acquisition and maintenance costs. Through this REU program, participants worked with faculty mentors from interdisciplinary areas to complete projects having high potential for enhancing our everyday communication experiences. By the end of the program, participants acquired valuable skills; gained a broader and deeper understanding of research, graduate life, and professional careers. They also developed greater confidence in their own abilities and be ready to further pursue research opportunities. 

We aimed at recruiting female students and students from underrepresented groups. We had increasing number of applicants each year. Table 1 is the brief applicant and participant demographics. In the three-year program, we had stable percentage of female participants as well as African/Hispanic American percentage. We especially contacted local community colleges, such as Moraine Valley Community College (2-year) and Morton College (4-year), with whom we have collaborated projects in the past. Each year, quite a few students from those colleges applied to our REU program. We admitted one from Morton College in 2015, one in 2016, and two from Moraine Valley Community College in 2017. 

All of our program participants experienced the research activities from literature search, problem formalization, solution design, to performance analysis. Weekly individual meeting and bi-weekly group meeting, luncheon, and workshop, all helped them to get familiar with their research projects, research facilities, and research partners. Field trips helped to bring the participants together which boosted their team work and collaboration spirit. 

Towards the end of the program, most of the participants were working on a technical paper summarizing their research outcomes for submission to peer-reviewed conferences/workshops. Paper writing further completed their research experience. 

Our REU site has expected achievements. We fulfilled our goal of providing the environment, guidance, and assistance to undergraduate student research. 

  • Publications. Table 1 shows the publications based on REU research project and authored by REU participants. We can see that more than half of the participants get their work published. A total of 12 papers are published, including 7 REUNS workshop papers and 5 conference papers. In the no-cost extension years (2018-2019), we hired 3 undergraduate students to continue to work on the REU projects. One paper was produced and published at an international conference. 
  • Higher education seeking.  Based on our end-of-program survey, most participants showed interest in further study for a higher degree in STEM disciplines. Due to the fact that we had quite a few students who were still sophomore, we do not have long enough time to see the result. For now, one African-American participant has applied and been admitted to the graduate program of our university; two participants from a 2-year community college has transferred to a 4-year university.
  • Mentor experience.  Each mentor supervised 2-3 students during each summer.  They reported typically meeting with students 1-2 times per week and communicating with them via email and/or text messaging outside of their meetings.  All mentors indicated that they enjoyed being part of the REU program and working with the undergraduate students. The mentors expressed joy in being able to see students who often came in with very little research experience grow as researchers and often present and/or publish their work. The PI and the evaluator co-authored a report on REU mentoring study and published in a computer science education oriented journal.  
  • Evaluation results. Overall, participants indicated their satisfaction with the REU program (Mean across years was 4.08 on a 5-point scale where 4 indicated satisfied) and their mentors (Mean across years was 4.18).  Specific mentor qualities rated highest by participants were related to mentors professional integrity, approachability, accessibility, and suggesting appropriate resources. Participants showed growth in confidence related to their research skills, particularly in relation to understanding primary research literature, discussing research at a professional conference/meeting, interpreting data analyses, and discussing research with professors.  Participants also reported increased knowledge related to research including the nature of the job of a researcher, research presentation preparation, and what graduate school is like.
